articles.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: Aladdin's father worked as a

qti-simple-choice._: baker

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have chosen baker because it’s a common job, but look at the lines, “His father worked as a tailor,” and, “Are you the son of the tailor?”—baker is never mentioned. The correct answer is tailor because the text names it twice. Next time, reread for exact clue words and pick the word the text repeats.

qti-simple-choice._: tailor

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by picking “tailor” as Aladdin’s father’s job. The text supports this when it says, “His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people,” and again when the stranger asks, “Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?” Remember to look for sentences that directly answer the question and repeat key words from the question in the passage.

qti-simple-choice._: farmer

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have guessed “farmer” or mixed it up with another story, but the text clearly says, “His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people,” and the stranger asks, “Are you the son of the tailor?”—so the father was a tailor, not a farmer. The correct answer is tailor because the story states it twice. Next time, reread the sentence that answers the question and underline the exact words from the text before choosing.

qti-simple-choice._: teacher

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have mixed up the job words and chose “teacher,” but the story says his father worked as a tailor, and the stranger asks if Aladdin is the son of the tailor. This shows the correct answer is tailor, not teacher. Next time, reread and match your answer to the exact word the story uses.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: Which word describes how Aladdin's mother most likely feels about meeting the stranger?

qti-simple-choice._: bored

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have guessed she was bored, but the text says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother,” which does not match “bored.” The right answer is “surprised” because the passage states it directly and explains why. Next time, reread the sentence that tells how the character feels and choose the word that matches it exactly.

qti-simple-choice._: angry

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have guessed she was angry because a stranger came, but the story doesn’t say that. It says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother,” so the correct answer is surprised, not angry. Next time, reread the sentence with feeling words and pick the word that matches what the text says.

qti-simple-choice._: excited

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the promise of good money and her welcoming him, which can sound exciting, but the text says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother,” so the correct answer is surprised. To find the right answer, look for the exact sentence that tells how the character feels and match your choice to that word.

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job identifying a key detail about the character’s feelings. The text says, “She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother.” Next time, look for feeling words and the reason that follows to confirm your answer.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: The reader can tell this story is a fantasy because

qti-simple-choice._: a stranger visits Aladdin's house

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on an early detail (the magician visiting), but the text says he “spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly… the earth split open,” showing the words caused it. That’s why the correct answer is “words make the earth split open.” Next time, reread the question for cause-and-effect and find the exact sentence that explains what made the event happen.

qti-simple-choice._: they climb up a steep mountain path

qti-feedback-inline._: It looks like you focused on an earlier detail (their climb), but the question asks what made the earth split. The text says, “he… spoke magical words… The earth split open right at their feet,” so the correct answer is that the words made the earth split. Next time, reread the sentence where the event happens and pick the detail that explains it.

qti-simple-choice._: words make the earth split open

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully recognized cause and effect by connecting the magician’s words to what happened next. The text supports this: “he… spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly… The earth split open right at their feet.” Remember to look for what happens right before a big change and ask, “What caused that?” when answering similar questions.

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin gathers dry sticks for a fire

qti-feedback-inline._: You likely focused on a small detail, but the text says, “Then he… spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly… The earth split open right at their feet,” showing the words caused it—not Aladdin gathering sticks. The correct answer is “words make the earth split open.” Strategy: Reread the lines around the big event and pick the cause the text points to, not an earlier step.

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: This story was most likely written to

qti-simple-choice._: show readers how magic lamps are found

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the detail of Aladdin finding the lamp, but the story isn’t a how-to; it shows what happens because of choices. Look at “He only cared about getting the magic lamp… he spoke a magic spell… Poor Aladdin was trapped”—the magician’s greed causes trouble. So the best answer is that the story teaches that greed can lead to trouble; next time, ask, What lesson do the characters learn from what happens?

qti-simple-choice._: interest readers in collecting gems

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the shiny gems and thought the author wants to interest readers in collecting them, but the text shows the opposite: “all those gems made his bag very heavy” so Aladdin couldn’t climb out, and the magician “only cared about getting the magic lamp” and trapped him. These details teach that greed leads to trouble, which is the main message. Next time, ask yourself, “Do the events show a benefit or a warning?” and choose the answer that matches the lesson of the whole passage.

qti-simple-choice._: teach readers that greed can lead to trouble

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job—you found the story’s lesson (theme) by noticing how greed leads to problems. The text shows this when “Aladdin…filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy…he could not pull himself out,” and when the magician “only cared about getting the magic lamp” and trapped Aladdin. Next time, look for warnings and then see what trouble follows a character’s choice to want too much to spot the theme.

qti-simple-choice._: make readers feel sorry for the magician

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the magician’s feelings instead of the main idea, but the text says "The magician grew very angry... He only cared about getting the magic lamp" and even says "Poor Aladdin," so we are not meant to feel sorry for the magician. The story’s lesson is that greed causes trouble: the magician’s greed makes him trap Aladdin, and Aladdin’s heavy bag of gems keeps him stuck. Next time, ask, "What lesson do the events show?" and look for clue words that cover the whole passage, not just one character’s feelings.

items.title: Quiz Question

p._: In the story, the magician tells Aladdin that finding the lamp will make him
p.b: "richer than any king in the world."

p: What does this phrase mean?

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin will have more money than he can count

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully made a good prediction by using clues about the magic lamp and treasure. The text supports this when it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the magician promises it “will make you richer than any king in the world.” Remember to look for repeated hints and strong words like “will” to predict what will happen next.

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin will become the ruler of a kingdom

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought “richer than any king” means Aladdin becomes a king, or you used what you know from other versions, but the text says the lamp “would make any person very rich” and “It will make you richer than any king,” which is about money, not ruling. So the correct answer is that Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: Reread and underline clue words like “rich/richer,” and choose the answer that matches exactly what the passage says—not what you expect from outside the story.

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin will find gold coins in the cave

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have brought in outside ideas (gold coins), but the text never mentions coins—Aladdin finds “beautiful gems,” and the lamp is said to make a person “very rich,” even “richer than any king.” That means the best prediction is about how much wealth he will have, not a specific kind of money, so “Aladdin will have more money than he can count” fits the text. Next time, stick to the exact words and look for clue phrases about the main idea, like “very rich.”

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin will meet kings from other countries

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the word “king” and guessed he’d meet kings, but the text never says Aladdin will meet any kings; it says the lamp “had amazing powers that would make any person very rich” and the treasure “will make you richer than any king in the world.” That evidence points to the correct answer: Aladdin will have more money than he can count. Strategy: reread for clue words and choose the option that matches what the passage actually says, not ideas it doesn’t mention.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: What causes the magician to trap Aladdin in the cave?

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin doesn't give him the lamp right away.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully understood cause and effect by noticing that Aladdin doesn’t give the lamp right away. The text supports this when the magician says, “First, hand me the lamp,” and Aladdin replies, “I cannot reach it right now.” Remember to reread what happens right before and after an event to see why it happens.

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin won't to go into the cave.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought Aladdin refused to go into the cave, but the story says he “agreed to help” and “went down into the dark cave below.” The problem is that “the lamp was buried deep in Aladdin’s heavy bag,” so he couldn’t reach it and didn’t give it to the magician right away—that’s why the correct answer is “Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away.” Next time, reread and find the exact sentence in the text that answers the question.

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin takes too many gems from the cave.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the gems, but the text shows the problem happens when Aladdin won’t give the lamp right away: “First, hand me the lamp… The magician grew very angry,” and then he seals the cave. So the correct answer is that Aladdin doesn’t hand over the lamp right away. Next time, reread the sentences just before the trouble to find the real cause.

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin breaks the magic ring on his finger.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have brought in an idea that isn’t in this part of the story (the ring breaking), but look at the text: “First, hand me the lamp…,” “I cannot reach it right now,” and “The magician grew very angry,” which shows he’s mad because Aladdin doesn’t give him the lamp right away. The passage never says the ring breaks; it only says the ring will keep him safe. To find the right answer, reread the lines around the event and look for cause-and-effect clue words (like “first,” “when”), and choose the option that matches what the text directly says.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: What is the central message or lesson of this story about Aladdin and the magician?

qti-simple-choice._: Magic can solve all of your problems if you believe in it.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the word “magic,” but look at how the magician lies about being Aladdin’s uncle, promises riches, and then uses magic to trap Aladdin in the cave—believing in magic doesn’t solve his problems, it creates them. This shows the real lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, check that your answer matches what happens in the whole story, especially the results of the characters’ actions.

qti-simple-choice._: Be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified the lesson by noticing how a stranger’s big promises led to trouble. The text supports this when the man promises to help Aladdin “learn to become a merchant and earn good money” and says the treasure will make him “richer than any king in the world,” but then he traps Aladdin in the cave. Remember, when finding a story’s lesson, ask yourself, “What happens after a character makes a big promise?”

qti-simple-choice._: Hard work is the only way to become wealthy and successful.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the detail that Aladdin’s mother works hard, but the story’s events point to a different lesson. Aladdin doesn’t become rich through hard work—the stranger pretends to be his uncle, promises to make him a merchant, then uses magic and traps Aladdin in the cave to get the lamp. This shows the real lesson: be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Strategy: Reread the whole passage and ask, “What warning does the story give?” so your answer matches the main message, not just one detail.

qti-simple-choice._: Always listen to your mother's advice about strangers.

qti-feedback-inline._: You might be thinking about what parents usually say about strangers, but in the story the mother doesn’t give advice—she believes the “uncle,” and he is really a magician. The man promises Aladdin he will “earn good money” and find a treasure “richer than any king,” then he tricks Aladdin and traps him, so the lesson is to be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises. Next time, reread and ask, “What lesson fits what actually happens in the whole story?”

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: Why does the magician pretend to be Aladdin’s uncle?

qti-simple-choice._: So he can help Aladdin become a rich merchant.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the promise to help Aladdin become a merchant, but the story says he was “a powerful magician” who came “to search for a special magic lamp,” and later he says, “First, hand me the lamp.” This shows his real goal was the lamp, not making Aladdin rich. The correct answer is that he wanted Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp. Next time, check the character’s actions and repeated clues, not just their first promise.

qti-simple-choice._: Because he is truly part of Aladdin’s family.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought he was truly family because he hugged Aladdin and called him 'nephew,' but the text says, "the stranger was not really Aladdin’s uncle at all" and later, "He only cared about getting the magic lamp." This shows he pretended to be family to get Aladdin to bring him the lamp, which is the correct answer. Next time, reread to find the sentence that tells a character’s real reason, not just their first actions or words.

qti-simple-choice._: To get Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified a character’s motive by noticing the magician pretended to be Aladdin’s uncle so Aladdin would bring him the lamp. The text supports this when it says he came “to search for a special magic lamp… [and] needed someone to help him,” and later he demands, “First, hand me the lamp.” Remember to ask yourself, “What does the character want?” and look for lines that state goals or demands when answering similar questions.

qti-simple-choice._: So he can take Aladdin for a long mountain walk.

qti-feedback-inline._: It looks like you focused on the long walk up the mountain, but the text says the magician came “to search for a special magic lamp,” told Aladdin “Bring that lamp back to me,” and “only cared about getting the magic lamp,” so his goal wasn’t the walk. The correct answer is that he took Aladdin to get him to bring the magic lamp. Next time, look for what the character wants most (the main goal) and make sure your answer matches that, not just one event.

articles.title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part II

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: In the story, Aladdin is like other people in danger because he

qti-simple-choice._: collected gems from the cave floor

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: Why did the author write this story about Aladdin?

qti-simple-choice._: to explain how genies grant wishes to people who find them

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the exciting detail of genies and wishes, but the text does not explain how genies work. It shows Aladdin being kind and clever: he gives the Sultan gems and uses the lamp to send “forty servants… each carrying a bowl full of gems,” so “the Sultan agreed that Aladdin could marry his daughter.” That means the main idea is that kindness and cleverness can lead to happiness. Next time, check what the whole story is mostly about, not just one exciting detail.

qti-simple-choice._: to show how kindness and cleverness can lead to happiness

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified the story’s message by noticing how Aladdin’s kindness and clever problem-solving lead to a happy ending. The text supports this when he “quickly said, ‘We are very hungry! Please bring us something to eat!’” and later uses the lamp to meet the Sultan’s challenge, after which “Aladdin was so happy!” and “They celebrated… all day and all night.” Remember to look at what the main character does to solve problems and how the story ends to figure out the theme in similar passages.

qti-simple-choice._: to teach people how to find magic lamps and genies

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the story teaches how to find magic lamps, but the text never gives steps; Aladdin meets the genies by accident when he rubs a ring while praying and when his mother cleans a dirty lamp. Instead, the story shows that kind, smart choices lead to good things—he says, “Please bring us something to eat,” meets the Sultan’s challenge with help, and it ends with a happy wedding and feast. Strategy: For main idea questions, ask if the passage is a how-to or a lesson, and check how the story ends.

qti-simple-choice._: to describe what life was like long ago

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the “long ago” setting, but the text doesn’t describe real life in the past—there are magical genies and no facts about daily life. Notice how Aladdin kindly asks for food for his mother and cleverly solves the Sultan’s demand with the genie’s help, which leads to a wedding and a palace; this shows the lesson that kindness and cleverness can lead to happiness. Next time, ask yourself: Is the author giving facts, or telling a story to teach a lesson?

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: Which best describes how this part of the story is organized?

qti-simple-choice._: telling what happens from start to finish

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified the sequence text structure by noticing the story is told from start to finish. The text shows this order with clues like “Then he remembered his magic ring,” “Then please take me,” and “Poof! Suddenly Aladdin was in Africa… Aladdin and his wife made a plan.” Remember to look for time-order words (first, then, suddenly, finally) to track what happens next in similar questions.

qti-simple-choice._: describing how to use a magic ring

qti-feedback-inline._: It’s easy to think this is about how to use a magic ring, but the text doesn’t give instructions; it tells a sequence of events: Aladdin walks by the river, remembers the ring, asks the genie, is taken to Africa, learns about the magician, and makes a plan. That shows the passage is telling what happens from start to finish. Next time, ask yourself: Is the author giving steps to follow, or telling a story in order? Look for action words and time order to decide.

qti-simple-choice._: telling how to find a lost palace

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the lost palace and thought the passage gives steps, but it never tells the reader how to find a palace; instead it shows events in order: Aladdin walks, remembers the ring, asks the genie, goes to Africa, learns the trick, and makes a plan. That start-to-finish sequence means the best answer is “telling what happens from start to finish.” Next time, look for clue words like then and suddenly to tell if it’s a story (events in order) or instructions (steps to follow).

qti-simple-choice._: explaining how to travel to different places

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the detail that Aladdin goes to Africa and thought it was about travel, but the passage never explains how to travel; it tells what happens to Aladdin. Look at the sequence: “He walked… then he remembered his magic ring… the genie appeared… Poof! Suddenly Aladdin was in Africa… Aladdin and his wife made a plan,” which shows events from start to finish. So the correct answer is “telling what happens from start to finish”; next time, check whether the text gives step-by-step instructions you could follow (how-to) or simply tells what happened first, next, and last (sequence).

items.title: Section 4 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: This story was most likely written to

qti-simple-choice._: teach readers that good wins over evil.

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job—you identified the story’s lesson (theme) by seeing that the good characters prevail over the evil one. The text shows this when “the magician… fell down and died,” and then “Aladdin lived peacefully and safely… and was fair and kind to all people.” Remember to look at how the problem is solved and what happens to the good and bad characters at the end to figure out the message in similar stories.

qti-simple-choice._: interest readers in learning about palaces.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the palace detail, but notice how the princess and Aladdin stop the evil magician (“the magician…fell down and died”), get the lamp back, and then live safely while Aladdin rules kindly. These events show that good wins over evil, which is the correct answer. Next time, make sure your choice matches the lesson of the whole story, not just one interesting detail.

qti-simple-choice._: make readers feel sorry for the magician.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the magician’s death and thought the story wants you to feel sorry for him, but the text shows he hid the lamp “in the magician’s sleeve,” and Aladdin and the princess stop him. After the genie returns the palace, there are “celebrations for a whole month,” and Aladdin becomes a fair, kind ruler—this shows the big idea is that good wins over evil. Tip: To find the main message, look at how the story ends and choose the answer that fits the whole passage, not just one part.

qti-simple-choice._: show readers how genies grant wishes.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the exciting detail of the genie, but the text doesn’t explain how genies grant wishes—the genie simply says, “I hear and I obey,” and moves the palace. The bigger idea is that the heroes stop the evil magician, the Sultan celebrates “for a whole month,” and Aladdin becomes “fair and kind,” showing that good wins over evil. Next time, check that your answer fits what the whole passage is mostly about, not just one part.

items.title: Quiz Question

p: Read the sentence.

p._: "The next morning, the Sultan woke up and looked out his window. He was so happy to see his daughter and her  again!"

p: What does the word palace mean?

qti-simple-choice._: a small house where poor people live

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought “palace” meant a small poor house, but the text says it is “the Sultan’s daughter’s palace” and the genie moves “the palace with everything inside it,” showing it’s very big and for important people. That’s why the correct answer is a large building where important people live. Next time, use the clues around the word—who owns it and what happens to it—to figure out its meaning.

qti-simple-choice._: a place where people go to buy things

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the lamp seller and thought of a place to buy things, but look at “The next morning, the Sultan looked out his window. His daughter’s palace was completely gone! So was the princess,” which shows the palace is where she lives, not a shop. The correct answer is “a large building where important people live.” Next time, reread the sentences around the word and check that your meaning fits the whole scene, not just one detail.

qti-simple-choice._: a building where soldiers stay and train

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have mixed up “palace” with a place for soldiers, but the text says “Aladdin’s palace,” “his daughter’s palace,” and that it was put next to the Sultan’s home—the princess and Aladdin live there, not soldiers. This shows palace means a large building where important people live. Next time, reread the sentence with the word and ask, “Who lives here?” to use context clues.

qti-simple-choice._: a large building where important people live

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully used context clues to figure out the meaning of the word “palace.” The text supports this when it shows important people living there—“the Sultan looked out his window” at his daughter’s palace—and when the genie moves “this palace with everything inside it… next to the Sultan’s home,” showing it’s a large building for important people. Remember: when you see a tricky word, look at who uses it and what happens around it to infer its meaning.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: In the story of Aladdin, why does the sorcerer disguise himself as a poor lamp seller shouting "New lamps for old"? What is he trying to get?

qti-simple-choice._: Aladdin's genie lamp by tricking the princess.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by naming what was stolen and how it happened. The text shows this when it says, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician. He gave her a new lamp that was not magic,” after he called, “New lamps for old lamps!” Remember to look for the who, what, and how in the same part of the passage and underline those clues to confirm your answer.

qti-simple-choice._: Goodwill by generously replacing worn-out lamps with new ones.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought he was being kind by replacing old lamps, but the story says he was the evil magician in disguise who shouted “New lamps for old lamps!” and then “hurried away with the real lamp,” which shows a trick, not kindness. So the correct answer is that he got Aladdin’s genie lamp by tricking the princess. Next time, reread what the character does after an offer to see if it is helpful or a trick.

qti-simple-choice._: Permission to work in the palace by offering free replacements.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought he was hired to work at the palace, but the story says he “walked by Aladdin’s palace and shouted, ‘New lamps for old lamps!’” and “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician,” so he tricked her into giving him the lamp, not a job. The correct answer is that he got Aladdin’s genie lamp by tricking the princess. Next time, reread the lines about the trade and ask, “What did each person give or get?” to be sure your answer matches the text.

qti-simple-choice._: Any old lamp that looks valuable so he can resell it for profit.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the cry “New lamps for old lamps!” and thought he wanted any valuable lamp to sell, but the story says, “This must be magic from the lamp!” and shows he dressed up to trick the princess into giving him Aladdin’s special lamp, which he then rubbed to use the genie. So the correct answer is that he wanted Aladdin’s genie lamp by tricking the princess. Strategy: Reread for lines that state a character’s goal, not just what they pretend to do.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: What is the central lesson or moral that this story teaches?

qti-simple-choice._: Magic can solve any problem if you believe in it

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the magic and thought belief could fix everything. But the text shows the problem starts when the princess trades the “old, ugly lamp,” the magician uses it to steal the palace, and even the ring genie says he cannot move it—so believing isn’t enough. The lesson is to be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its worth. Strategy: Reread and ask, “What choice caused the big problem?” then pick the answer that warns against that mistake.

qti-simple-choice._: It is better to be poor than to have nice things

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the story says rich things are bad, but the text doesn’t say that—Aladdin stays wealthy and later becomes a kind ruler. Look at when the princess trades the “old, ugly” lamp for a shiny one and then the palace disappears; this shows the lesson: be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its worth. Next time, focus on the main mistake and its consequence to find the story’s lesson.

qti-simple-choice._: Be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its true worth

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully found the story’s lesson by noticing that the princess gave away something valuable without knowing its worth. The text supports this when it says, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician,” and afterward the palace was “completely gone.” Remember, to find the lesson in stories, look at a character’s choice and what happens because of it.

qti-simple-choice._: Always trust strangers who offer to trade with you because you might get unexpected rewards

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the trade led to a good surprise, but the text says, “The princess gave Aladdin’s magic lamp to the magician… [he] moved the palace,” which shows trusting the stranger caused big trouble, not rewards. The lesson is to be careful not to give away something valuable without knowing its worth—the princess didn’t know the “old, ugly” lamp was magic and lost everything. Next time, check what happens after a choice in the story (the result) and choose the answer that matches that main outcome.

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: Based on the story, Alice is probably

qti-simple-choice._: happy to be working hard

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the idea of making a daisy chain and thought Alice was happy to work, but the text says she was getting very tired of sitting, there was nothing fun to do, and she even wondered if picking flowers was worth all that work. These clues show she was bored and sleepy, not eager to work, so the correct answer is bored with sitting by the river. Next time, reread for feeling words and make sure your choice matches how the character feels in the whole passage.

qti-simple-choice._: excited about her sister's book

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the mention of her sister’s book and assumed Alice was excited, but the text says she was “very tired” and the book had “no pictures” or “talking,” and she even thinks, “What good is a book without pictures or talking?” These clues show she isn’t excited—she’s bored with sitting by the river, which is the correct answer. Next time, look for feeling words and clue phrases like “tired” and “nothing fun to do” to make sure your choice matches what the story actually says.

Remember to look for feeling words and clues in the first sentences to figure out how a character feels in a passage.

qti-feedback-inline._: It looks like you focused on the surprising White Rabbit at the end, but the text says, “Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river” and “There was nothing fun to do,” which shows she was bored—not worried. To find the right answer, notice what the passage talks about the most at the beginning and choose “bored with sitting by the river.” Next time, check that your answer matches what the whole passage is about, not just one exciting detail.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: How does Alice's situation change from the beginning to the end of the section?

qti-simple-choice._: Alice goes from running very fast to moving very slowly.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the detail about speed, but look at the text: “Alice jumped up…ran after the Rabbit” and then “Alice found herself falling down…a very deep well,” which shows the real change is from being on the ground to falling, not from fast to slow. The correct answer is that she goes from standing on the ground to falling down a deep well. Next time, reread what changes from one sentence to the next and choose the answer that matches the main change in the scene.

qti-simple-choice._: Alice goes from following the Rabbit to leading the way.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on who was in front, but the question asks what changes for Alice. The text says she “ran after the Rabbit,” “followed the Rabbit down the hole,” and then “found herself falling down a very deep well,” so she never leads; the real change is from standing on the ground to falling. Next time, reread and look for words that show what happens to the main character (moved, fell, went) to find the change.

qti-simple-choice._: Alice goes from being curious about the Rabbit to being afraid of it.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have guessed Alice felt afraid, but the text never says that—she “did not think this was strange,” “ran after the Rabbit,” and then “found herself falling down a very deep well.” The real change is from standing on the ground to falling down the well, which matches the correct answer. Next time, reread the beginning and ending to see what changes, and choose the answer that is clearly stated in the passage.

qti-simple-choice._: Alice goes from standing on the ground to falling down a deep well.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully sequenced events by identifying key details that show how Alice’s situation changes. items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Read this sentence from the story: "Alice was not hurt at all." In that sentence, hurt means "injured" (physical harm to the body). Which sentence uses hurt with the same meaning?

qti-simple-choice._: The coach said the loss won't hurt our chances in the playoffs.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have matched “hurt” to mean “cause harm,” but look at the text: “Alice was not hurt at all,” which talks about her body after a fall. “The coach said the loss won’t hurt our chances” uses “hurt” about chances, not a person’s injury, so it doesn’t match. The correct choice is “The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee,” because it uses “hurt” as a physical injury like in the passage. Strategy: Reread the sentence with the word and ask, “Is it about a person being injured or something like chances being harmed?” and pick the one that matches the passage’s meaning.

qti-simple-choice._: The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by focusing on what happened to the girl after she fell. The text supports this when it says, “Down, down, down she fell… thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves.” Remember to double-check the exact words about what happens next so your answer matches the text closely on future questions.

qti-simple-choice._: His rude comment hurt his sister's feelings.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have brought in ideas that aren’t in the story, but the text shows only Alice falling—“Down, down, down she fell… Alice was not hurt at all”—and there’s no boy, sister, or rude comment. To find the right answer, pick the choice about a girl falling (The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee) because it’s the only option that matches the passage’s main event; next time, underline key words and match them to the choices.

qti-simple-choice._: It won't hurt to ask your teacher for help.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have chosen advice that’s not in the story, but look at the text: it only describes the girl falling—“Down, down, down she fell… thump!”—and never mentions a teacher. To find the right answer, pick the one that tells what happened to her (The girl fell off her bike and hurt her knee), and next time reread to make sure your choice matches details from the passage.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: How does each section of the story build on Alice's problem of changing sizes?

qti-simple-choice._: Each section shows Alice solving her size problems easily and quickly

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the times Alice tries to fix things, but the text shows it isn’t easy: she shrinks and can’t reach the key, then grows to nine feet and can’t fit through the door, cries a pool, and even shrinks into it. The correct idea is that each section adds a new size change that makes bigger problems until the Caterpillar explains the mushroom, and Alice uses tiny bites to control her size. Next time, reread what happens from beginning to end and pick the answer that fits the whole pattern, not just one moment.

qti-simple-choice._: Each section repeats the same problem without Alice learning anything new

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the story just repeats the same size problem, but it actually changes each time: first Alice is too small for the key, then too big for the door, and finally the Caterpillar tells her, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter,” and she eats tiny bites until she is back to normal. This shows each section adds a new size change that makes things harder until she learns to control her size. Next time, read from start to finish and ask, “How does the problem change, and what does the character learn?”

qti-simple-choice._: Each section adds a new size change that creates bigger problems until she finds control

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully recognized the sequence and cause-and-effect by seeing how each part shows Alice’s size change creating a new problem until she gains control. The text shows this: “she was only ten inches tall… had forgotten the little golden key,” then “I am growing bigger and bigger… much too big to fit through the doorway,” and later the Caterpillar says, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller,” which helps her get back to normal. Remember to track what happens first, next, and last, and ask, “What new problem does this change cause?” when you read similar stories.

qti-simple-choice._: Each section shows Alice getting bigger, then smaller, then finding a solution

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have looked for a repeating pattern, but the text shows first Alice gets smaller and can’t reach the key, then she grows too big and even shrinks into her tear pool, and only in the last part the Caterpillar’s mushroom helps her control her size. This means each part adds a new size change that causes bigger problems until she learns control—not “bigger, then smaller, then solution” each time. Next time, reread each part and check that your answer matches what actually happens in all parts, not a pattern you expect.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: In the story, which problem happens to Alice more than once?

qti-simple-choice._: She grows and shrinks over and over after eating or drinking.

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job! You successfully identified a pattern and key details by noticing that Alice changes size whenever she eats or drinks. The text shows this when it says, “She was getting smaller and smaller” after the bottle, “Now I am growing bigger and bigger!” after the cake, and the Caterpillar explains, “One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter.” Remember to look for repeated events and cause-and-effect clues (like what happens after she eats or drinks) when answering similar questions.

qti-simple-choice._: She keeps losing her shoes.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the line “I can barely see my feet” and turned it into “losing shoes,” but the story never mentions shoes. Instead, it shows a pattern: she shrinks after drinking from the bottle, grows huge after eating the “EAT ME” cake, and later changes size again by eating mushroom pieces. So the correct answer is that she grows and shrinks over and over after eating or drinking. Next time, reread for exact words and look for events that repeat to find the main idea.

qti-simple-choice._: She keeps getting locked out of her house.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the door mix-up and thought she was locked out of a house. But the story says she “was getting smaller,” the cake made her “growing bigger and bigger,” later she was “getting smaller again,” and the Caterpillar explains the mushroom can make her taller or shorter. This shows the main thing that keeps happening is her size changing after she eats or drinks, which is why the correct answer is that she grows and shrinks over and over. Tip: look for what happens again and again to find the best answer.

qti-simple-choice._: She keeps turning invisible whenever she talks.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the line “as she spoke” meant she turned invisible, but the text says she is “getting smaller and smaller” and later “growing bigger and bigger”—it never says she disappears. The correct answer is that Alice keeps shrinking and growing after she eats or drinks (bottle, cake, mushroom). Next time, reread for the exact words that tell what changes (smaller, bigger, grow, shrink) and make sure your answer matches those words.

articles.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Part III

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: In the story, what causes Alice to ask the Cheshire Cat for help?

qti-simple-choice._: She wants to see the Cat's big smile.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on a small detail—the Cat’s big smile—but the passage clearly says, “She wanted to find her way home,” and she even asks which way she should go, showing her goal is getting home, not looking at the smile. The correct answer is that she wants to find her way home because the text states it directly. Strategy: Reread the sentence that tells the character’s goal and make sure your answer matches that main idea.

qti-simple-choice._: She wants to sit down and rest.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have taken “getting tired” to mean she needed a rest, but the text says, “She was getting tired of all the odd things in Wonderland. She wanted to find her way home,” and she asks the Cat which way to go. So the correct answer is that she wants to find her way home. Next time, reread the sentence after a tricky word and pick the choice that matches what the text says directly.

qti-simple-choice._: She wants to find her way home.

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job identifying a key detail by noticing what Alice wanted. The text supports this when it says, “She wanted to find her way home.” Next time, look for sentences that clearly tell what a character wants or does, and use those words in your answer.

qti-simple-choice._: She wants to climb the tree branch.

qti-feedback-inline._: It looks like you focused on the tree detail instead of Alice’s goal—the passage never says she wants to climb the branch. The text clearly states, “She wanted to find her way home,” and she asks the Cat “which way I should go,” showing her aim is to get home. Next time, look for a sentence that directly tells what the character wants and make sure your answer matches the main idea, not just one detail.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

p: Read this sentence from the story.
'Alice looked around the whole table carefully.' Which sentence uses the word table the same as it is used in the sentence above?

qti-simple-choice._: We will table the discussion until our next meeting.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have picked the sentence where “table” is an action (to put off a discussion), but in the story “table” is a thing you can sit at. Look at “a large table set up for tea” and “she sat down … at the end of the table”—that shows it’s furniture. So the best choice is “The wooden table in the kitchen seats six people,” because it also means the piece of furniture; next time, match the word’s meaning by rereading how it’s used in the passage.

qti-simple-choice._: The wooden table in the kitchen seats six people.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by focusing on how the story describes the table and seating. The text supports this when it says there was “a large table set up for tea time,” that they were “crowded together at just one corner,” and Alice insists, “There is plenty of room!” Remember to look for describing words and numbers in the passage to make sure your answer matches what the text actually says.

qti-simple-choice._: Can you table all the important points from the book?

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought table meant “to list” ideas, but the text says “a large table set up for tea time” and Alice sits “at the end of the table,” showing it’s a piece of furniture. That’s why “Can you table all the important points…?” uses a different meaning and is incorrect; the correct match is “The wooden table in the kitchen seats six people,” which also means a furniture table. Strategy: When a word can mean different things, reread the sentence and ask which meaning fits—could you sit at it here?

qti-simple-choice._: The math table shows that two plus two equals four.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought of “table” as a math chart, but the passage says there was “a large table set up for tea time” and that the characters were “sitting at the table,” so it’s a real table, not about math. The correct answer is “The wooden table in the kitchen seats six people” because it also describes a table people sit at, which matches how the story uses the word. Next time, reread the lines about the object and choose the answer that fits how the word is used in the passage.

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

p: Read the sentence from the passage.
"Alice was sure she had never studied any of these subjects in her real school."
What does this sentence tell us about Alice's experience in Wonderland?

qti-simple-choice._: Alice is confused because she forgot her school subjects.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought Alice was confused because she forgot, but the story says the Mock Turtle and Gryphon learned “Reeling, Writhing, and Ambition,” and Alice “was sure she had never studied any of these,” so the confusion comes from Wonderland’s strange subjects, not her memory. This shows she realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world. Tip: Reread the lines with clues and check if your answer matches what the story actually says.

qti-simple-choice._: Alice thinks Wonderland school is better than her school.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought Alice liked the Wonderland school more, but the text says she had “never studied any of these subjects” and that “the conversation was very odd and confusing,” which shows it felt strange to her, not better. The correct answer is that Alice realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world because the subjects and creatures are unlike anything she knows. Next time, reread for clue words about feelings (like odd, confusing) and make sure your answer matches what the whole passage says, not what you assume.

qti-simple-choice._: Alice realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world.

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job—you successfully found the main idea by noticing that Alice realizes Wonderland is unlike her real world. The text shows this when she meets “strange creatures” like the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon and says she “had never studied any of these subjects in her real school.” Next time, ask yourself, “What is this mostly about?” and underline key details that show differences between settings.

qti-simple-choice._: Alice wants to learn the new subjects she heard about.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought Alice wanted to learn the new subjects, but the text says the subjects had “funny names,” the talk was “very odd and confusing,” and she was “sure she had never studied any of these,” which shows confusion, not interest. These clues—plus the strange creatures and answers that “didn’t make sense”—show that Alice realizes Wonderland is very different from her real world. Next time, reread to find words that show how the character feels and make sure your choice matches what the text actually says.

p: Read the sentence from Paragraph 2 of this section.
What does the phrase "Hold your tongue!" mean in this sentence?

qti-simple-choice._: be quiet

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully used context clues to figure out the phrase’s meaning by seeing that when the Queen yelled, “Hold your tongue!” and Alice replied, “I won’t!”, it shows the Queen wanted her to be quiet. The Queen’s angry reaction (“The Queen’s face turned purple with anger”) also supports that she was demanding silence. Remember to use what characters say and how they react to decode tricky phrases in future passages.

qti-simple-choice._: grab it

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have read the phrase literally and thought it meant to “grab it,” but notice the talk around it: Alice says, “Stuff and nonsense!” and after “Hold your tongue!” she answers, “I won’t!”—showing the Queen wanted her to stop talking, not grab her tongue. In this scene, “Hold your tongue!” is an expression meaning be quiet. Next time, use the sentences before and after a tricky phrase to see if it’s about speaking or a real action.

qti-simple-choice._: bite it

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have read “Hold your tongue!” as “bite it,” but notice the scene: Alice “said loudly,” the Queen turned “purple with anger,” and Alice replied, “I won’t!”—all showing the Queen wanted her to stop talking. So the phrase means “be quiet,” not to bite her tongue. Tip: When a phrase sounds odd, reread and ask, “What meaning fits what’s happening in the story?”

qti-simple-choice._: stick it out

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have taken “Hold your tongue!” literally and thought it meant “stick it out,” but look at the scene: after Alice speaks loudly, “The Queen’s face turned purple with anger. ‘Hold your tongue!’” This shows the Queen wants Alice to stop talking, so “be quiet” is the correct choice. Next time, use the feelings and actions in the sentence to check if a phrase is an expression, not a literal action.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Which choice best describes how the sections, in order, develop Alice’s adventure from the beginning to the end of the passage?

qti-simple-choice._: Each section introduces a new episode in Wonderland, moving the plot forward from entering the garden to her waking up.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified how the parts build the story by noticing the sequence of events from the garden to the wake-up. The text supports this when it says “she entered the garden,” then “The croquet game was very strange,” later “A trial was starting!” and finally “Just at that moment, Alice woke up!” Remember to track what happens first, next, then last by using paragraph breaks and clue words to guide your answer.

qti-simple-choice._: Each section explains the rules of a different game Alice plays with the Queen, building up to the trial.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the croquet game, but the later parts aren’t about game rules: Alice meets the Mock Turtle and Gryphon and hears about school subjects, then “Suddenly… a trial was starting,” and “Just at that moment, Alice woke up!” The right idea is that each section is a new episode that moves the story from entering the garden to waking up. Strategy: Check that your answer fits all sections, not just one, and use clue words like “Suddenly” and “Just at that moment” to see how the plot moves.

qti-simple-choice._: Each section presents a school lesson taught by a new teacher, ending when Alice meets her sister in class.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the word “school” and pictured classroom lessons with a new teacher, but the text shows different adventures: Alice plays croquet in the garden, meets the Mock Turtle and Gryphon, goes to a trial, and then wakes up by the river with her sister—not in a class. The right idea is that each part is a new event in Wonderland that moves the story along from entering the garden to waking up. Next time, stick to what the passage says and check how each section adds the next step of the story.

qti-simple-choice._: Each section repeats the same scene with small changes, keeping Alice in one place until she sails away.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have brought in another part of the story and thought the scenes repeat, but this passage shows new events each time: Alice enters the garden to play croquet, then meets the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon, then runs to a trial, and finally wakes up. So the right answer is that each section adds a new part of the adventure, moving from entering the garden to waking up. Strategy: Reread the first and last lines of each paragraph to see how the place and action change, and use only what this passage says (there is no sailing away here).

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Which body of water is the main setting of the story?

qti-simple-choice._: a river

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified a key detail about the setting by noticing the characters travel on a river. The text supports this when it says “They paddled around a bend in the river” and mentions sending “a boat down the river.” Remember to scan for repeated place words (like river and boathouse) to confirm where the story is happening.

qti-simple-choice._: the ocean

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have pictured boats on the ocean, but the text repeatedly says “paddle up the river,” “around a bend in the river,” and calls Toad Hall “the finest house on the whole river,” which rules out the ocean. The correct answer is a river because the story directly names the setting several times. Next time, underline exact place words in the passage and make sure your answer matches those words, not what you imagine.

qti-simple-choice._: a lake

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have picked “lake” because boats can be on lakes, but the text says, “They paddled around a bend in the river” and Toad would “send a boat down the river,” so the setting is a river. The correct answer is a river because the passage repeats that word. Next time, reread for exact place words the author uses.

qti-simple-choice._: a pond

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have pictured a small pond because the boathouse was quiet, but the text says 'They paddled around a bend in the river,' Toad would 'send a boat down the river,' and it's 'the finest house on the whole river.' These clues show it is a river, not a pond. Next time, underline the exact place words in the passage and pick the answer that matches those words.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: Based on his words and actions in the story, Toad most likely feels

qti-simple-choice._: proud.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details to figure out the character’s feeling by noticing how Toad talks about his house. The text supports this when it says, “It’s the finest house on the whole river,” and even notes he spoke “proudly.” Remember to look for feeling words and what a character says about something to decide their emotion in future readings.

qti-simple-choice._: lonely.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the “empty and quiet” boathouse and thought Toad felt lonely, but the text says, “It’s the finest house on the whole river,” cried Toad proudly, and he dances and is “always happy to see you,” which shows pride, not loneliness. The correct answer is proud because the author directly uses the clue word proudly to name his feeling. Next time, look for feeling words the author uses after dialogue (like proudly) and make sure your choice matches those clues.

qti-simple-choice._: insecure.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought Toad felt insecure (unsure), but the text says, “It’s the finest house on the whole river,” and even “cried Toad proudly,” which shows the opposite. The correct answer is proud because he brags and says his house is the best. Next time, look for feeling clue words (like proudly) and make sure your choice matches what the text says.

qti-simple-choice._: worried.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought his rushing ("I had orders ready... you must come") meant worried, but the text says "cried Toad proudly" and he boasts, "It’s the finest house on the whole river," which shows pride, not worry. The correct answer is proud because the story names that feeling and shows him bragging. Strategy: Look for feeling words and actions in the text and pick the word that matches them.

items.title: Quiz Question

p: Read the sentence from the passage.
"Maybe he's not very smart—we can't all be clever. He might be someone who brags a lot and thinks too highly of himself. But Toady is a great friend."
What does this sentence mean?

qti-simple-choice._: Smart animals make the best friends.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought smart animals make the best friends, but Rat says, “Maybe he’s not very smart… But Toady is a great friend,” which shows the opposite. This points to the real idea: friends have flaws but are still valuable. Next time, reread and look for clue words like “but” that show the author’s main point.

qti-simple-choice._: Friends have flaws but are still valuable.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully found the message about friendship by noticing that Rat values Toad even though he has flaws. The text shows this when Rat admits, “Maybe he’s not very smart… he brags… but Toady is a great friend,” and calls him “the same friendly fellow… always happy to see you.” Remember to look for clue words like “but” and how characters talk about each other to figure out the message in future stories.

qti-simple-choice._: Friends who brag should not be trusted.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on Toad’s bragging and thought that means he shouldn’t be trusted, but Rat says, “He might brag… but Toady is a great friend,” and also that he is “always the same friendly fellow.” This shows the main point: friends have flaws but are still valuable. Next time, look for clue words like “but” and make sure your answer matches what the whole passage says, not just one detail.

qti-simple-choice._: Clever animals are better than simple ones.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the words clever and simple and thought the story says clever animals are better. But Rat says, “Maybe he’s not very smart… he might brag… but Toady is a great friend,” and calls him “the best of animals” who is “always friendly,” showing that friends can have flaws and still be valuable. Next time, reread the lines around your clue words and choose the answer that matches the story’s big idea, not just one detail.

qti-prompt.p: The author most likely included the description of the empty boathouse to show

qti-simple-choice._: how Toad's interests and hobbies change quickly.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully found the main idea by noticing that the story shows Toad quickly dropping one hobby for another. The text supports this when Rat says, “Boating is old news now. Toad got tired of it,” and when “none of the boats were in the water.” Remember to ask yourself, “What is this mostly about?” and look for key sentences that show a character switching activities.

qti-simple-choice._: why Rat and Mole needed to find a place to leave their boat.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the small detail of where to leave the boat, but that line is just a quick direction; right after, the empty, quiet boathouse and Rat’s words, “Boating is old news now. Toad got tired of it,” show that Toad keeps switching hobbies. The correct answer is how Toad’s interests and hobbies change quickly, as Rat even wonders “what new hobby he likes now.” Next time, pick the idea that fits the whole passage, not just one small part.

qti-simple-choice._: how many different types of boats Toad owned at his house.

qti-feedback-inline._: It looks like you focused on the boats, but the text only says there were “many big boats” and that “none of the boats were in the water,” not how many types there were. Rat says, “Boating is old news now. Toad got tired of it and stopped doing it,” and Toad is already excited about something new—this shows his interests and hobbies change quickly. Next time, check that your answer fits what the whole passage is showing, not just one detail you notice.

qti-simple-choice._: what kind of expensive things wealthy animals can afford to buy.

qti-feedback-inline._: I can see why you noticed Toad’s fancy house and the line “Toad has lots of money,” but the text doesn’t talk about what expensive things animals buy. Look at “Boating is old news now. Toad got tired of it and stopped doing it” and the empty boathouse—these show the main idea is how Toad’s interests and hobbies change quickly. Next time, check that your answer fits what the whole passage is mostly about, not just one detail, and reread for clue sentences that state the main idea.

qti-prompt.p: How does the author mostly tell the story about Toad's visit with Rat and Mole?

qti-simple-choice._: by showing what the characters say to each other

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by noticing that the author uses dialogue to show what is happening. The text supports this with lines like “You must help me with something very important!” and “Oh no! Boating is silly!” which reveal Toad’s feelings through what he says. Remember to look for quotation marks and ask, “What do the characters’ words show about them?” when answering similar questions.

qti-simple-choice._: by describing how characters look

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the line “He made a face like he had tasted something bad” and thought the author shows it by describing how characters look. But most of the passage uses what they say—“You must help me…,” “Oh no! Boating is silly!,” “I don’t like boating anymore”—to show what’s happening, so the correct answer is that the author shows it by what the characters say to each other. Next time, scan for quotation marks and pick the choice that matches how the author mostly tells the information.

qti-simple-choice._: by comparing different activities

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the author was comparing activities, but the text doesn’t compare them; we learn from what the characters say: “Do you want us to help you with your boat?” and “Oh no! Boating is silly!” So the right answer is by showing what the characters say to each other (dialogue). Tip: Look for quotation marks to spot dialogue and ask, What do their words tell me?

qti-simple-choice._: by listing steps to solve a problem

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought the passage lists steps to solve a problem, but look at the lines in quotes—“You must help me…,” “Do you want us…,” and “Oh no! Boating is silly!”—which show the characters talking to each other, not steps like first/next/then. The author tells the story by showing what the characters say to each other, so “by showing what the characters say to each other” is correct. Strategy: When you see lots of quotation marks, think dialogue; for steps, look for words like first, next, and finally.

Those clues show he was upset about the trip, which is why the correct answer is that he was unhappy with the travel plans. qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: Read the sentence from the passage: "I feel sorry that you two still think about boats all the time. I found something much better to do!" Based only on this sentence, what does Toad think about his friends' interest in boats?

qti-simple-choice._: He wants to teach them a new activity.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on Toad showing them the wagon and a trip, but the passage never says he wants to teach them anything. Look at his words: “Boating is silly… I don’t like boating anymore. It’s just a waste of time,” which shows he thinks boats are a bad choice. Next time, reread the character’s exact words and look for clue words that show their opinion.

qti-simple-choice._: He thinks boats are a bad choice.

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job—you identified key details by noticing Toad’s opinion in his own words. The text says, “Boating is silly… It’s just a waste of time,” which shows he thinks boats are a bad choice. Remember, when a question asks about a character’s opinion, look for strong feeling words in their dialogue to find the answer.

qti-simple-choice._: He is afraid of boats and water.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought Toad was scared, but look at “Boating is silly!” and “It’s just a waste of time,” which show he dislikes boats because he thinks they’re a bad choice—not because he’s afraid. The correct idea is that Toad thinks boats are a bad choice and prefers the wagon. Next time, underline the words that show feelings (like “silly” or “waste of time”) and ask, “Does this show fear or just an opinion?”

qti-simple-choice._: He is angry because they won't listen to him.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have mixed up who “he” is and thought about Rat being upset, but the text says, “Oh no! Boating is silly!... He made a face like he had tasted something bad,” which shows Toad dislikes boats—not that people won’t listen to him. The right idea is that Toad thinks boats are a bad choice. Next time, reread the sentence before and after the pronoun to see who it refers to and use the exact words as your clue.

items.title: Quiz Question

qti-prompt.p: PART B: Based on what each character says and does, what can you conclude about how their different points of view create a problem in the story?

qti-simple-choice._: Toad's excitement makes Rat and Mole argue about who should make decisions

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on Toad’s excitement and thought it made Rat and Mole argue about who decides, but the text shows there isn’t an argument—Rat says, “I’m not coming… Mole is going to stay with me too,” and Mole answers, “Of course I’ll stick with you… but it does sound like it might be fun.” This shows Mole feels pulled two ways: he is loyal to Rat but also wants the adventure, which is why the correct answer is about Mole’s loyalty vs. his desire. Next time, reread the key lines and ask, “What problem is the character feeling inside?” and look for clue words like loyal and tempting.

qti-simple-choice._: All three friends want different things, so they decide to split up permanently

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought they split up for good, but the text says, “We don’t have to decide right now,” and Mole says, “I’ll stick with you, Rat,” which shows they stay together and haven’t decided to split. The real problem is inside Mole: he wants to be loyal to Rat but also wants the adventure—“But it does sound like it might be fun.” Next time, reread the key lines and look for clue words like “loyal” and “tempting” to be sure your answer matches what the text actually says, not a guess about what might happen.

qti-simple-choice._: Rat's anger about the wagon makes Toad want to find new friends for his trip

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on Rat’s anger and guessed Toad would look for new friends, but look at Rat saying, 'I'm not coming… Mole is going to stay with me,' and Toad begging, 'You have to come with me,' which shows Toad still wants Rat and Mole, not new friends. To find the right answer, notice Mole says, 'Of course I’ll stick with you, Rat,' but also, 'it might be fun,' so his loyalty to Rat goes against his wish for adventure. Next time, reread what each character says and ask, “What is the main problem between the characters?” not just how one feels.

qti-simple-choice._: Mole's loyalty to Rat conflicts with his desire for adventure

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified a character’s conflict by noticing that Mole wants two different things. The text shows this when he says, “Of course I’ll stick with you, Rat,” but then adds, “it does sound like it might be fun,” and the narrator notes the adventure was “very exciting and tempting.” Next time, look for what a character wants and what gets in the way to find the problem in the story.

items.title: Section 1 - Guiding Question

qti-prompt.p: The passage about Toad Hall is best described as

qti-simple-choice._: a play

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have picked “a play” because the characters talk, but a play shows character names and stage directions before lines. Here, a narrator tells what happens—“Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall” and “He told Mole all about the fun they would have”—so the correct answer is “a story.” Next time, check the format: look for speaker labels or stage directions to see if it’s a play.

qti-simple-choice._: a poem

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought it was a poem because of the title, but the passage uses sentences and paragraphs to tell what characters do—“Toad talked to Mole…” and “they loaded up the wagon and set off”—not short lines or stanzas. That means the correct answer is a story, since it narrates events in order with characters (Toad, Mole, Rat). Strategy: Check the text’s structure—poems have line breaks and often rhyme, while stories have paragraphs, characters, and a sequence of events.

qti-simple-choice._: a story

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified the text type by noticing story elements like characters, a setting, and events. The text supports this when it says, “Toad talked to Mole about taking a trip… after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure,” which shows a sequence of actions with characters. Remember to look for who the characters are, where they are, and what happens first, next, and last to tell if a passage is a story.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have picked “a report” because it’s about a trip, but look at “Lunch was wonderful at Toad Hall,” “He told Mole all about the fun,” “Mole got so excited,” and “they set off on their adventure”—these show characters, feelings, and events happening, not just facts. That means the passage is a story, because it tells what Toad, Mole, and Rat did and how they felt. Strategy: Ask, “Does this tell events with characters and emotions (a story) or give only facts and information (a report)?”

items.title: Section 2 - Guiding Question

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: After Toad stretches out his legs and says, "This is the real life for a gentleman!", what happens next in the story?

qti-simple-choice._: They have a pleasant trip on the narrow roads.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by paying attention to what happened before the highway. The text supports your answer when it says, “They had a pleasant trip along the narrow country roads.” Remember to scan for the exact words from the question and reread the nearby sentences to confirm your choice.

qti-simple-choice._: They stop to talk with other travelers on the road.

qti-feedback-inline._: It looks like you focused on a small detail—“Other travelers called out ‘Good day!’… Some people stopped to say nice things”—instead of the main idea. The text clearly says, “They had a pleasant trip along the narrow country roads,” so the correct answer is that they had a pleasant trip, not that they stopped to talk. Next time, check who is doing the action and pick the answer that matches the big idea of the sentence.

qti-simple-choice._: They choose a different route to avoid the highway.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought they avoided the highway, but the text says, “They had a pleasant trip along the narrow country roads… until they reached the big highway. That is where disaster struck,” so they did not choose a different route. The correct answer is that they have a pleasant trip on the narrow roads, which matches the sentence in the passage. Strategy: Reread for clue words like “until” to follow what happened first and what happened next.

qti-simple-choice._: Disaster strikes them right away.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the word disaster and thought it happened right away, but the text says they had a pleasant trip on the narrow roads and everything was going well until the big highway—that is where disaster struck. So the correct answer is that they have a pleasant trip first. Next time, look for clue words like until to track when events happen.

items.title: Section 3 - Guiding Question

qti-choice-interaction.qti-prompt: What was the very first sound the people heard from the dust cloud?

qti-simple-choice._: A faint 'toot-toot'

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified a key detail by choosing the exact sound the characters heard. The text supports this: “From the dust cloud, they heard a faint ‘toot-toot!’” Next time, reread the part of the passage that matches the question and underline the sentence that gives the direct answer.

qti-simple-choice._: A loud whirling noise

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the exciting part when it rushed past them (“a whirl of loud sound”), but the question asks what they heard from the dust cloud. The text says, “From the dust cloud, they heard a faint ‘toot-toot!’,” so the correct answer is A faint “toot-toot.” Next time, line up the question with the exact moment in the story and reread that sentence.

qti-simple-choice._: A big blast of wind

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the exciting moment when it whooshed past them, but the text says, “From the dust cloud, they heard a faint ‘toot-toot!’,” while the “big blast of wind” happened later “when it was right on top of them.” So the correct answer is “a faint ‘toot-toot,’” because that is what they heard from the dust cloud. Next time, match the question’s words to the exact sentence in the story and check the order of events.

qti-simple-choice._: Footsteps running closer

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have imagined footsteps because the noise got loud later, but the passage never mentions footsteps. It says, “From the dust cloud, they heard a faint ‘toot-toot!’” — that is the first sound they heard, so the correct answer is A faint “toot-toot.” Next time, underline the exact words that answer the question and pick the choice that matches those words.

p: Read the sentence from the story.
'You road hogs!'
This sentence means that Rat thought the drivers were

qti-simple-choice._: lost

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have picked “lost” because the dust made it hard to see and the wagon ended up in the ditch, but the text shows the car “threw a huge cloud of dust” and sped off while Rat called them “mean drivers” and “road hogs,” which points to selfish behavior. The correct answer is “selfish” because the drivers caused trouble and didn’t stop to help. Next time, check that your word describes the people’s actions and character, not just what happened around them.

qti-simple-choice._: hungry

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have thought of “hog” as an animal that eats a lot and chose “hungry,” but look at “You mean drivers! You road hogs!” after the car scares the horse and crashes their wagon—Rat is upset because the drivers were selfish, taking the road for themselves. The correct idea is selfish, not hungry. Next time, reread the words around the tricky phrase and use the actions and feelings in the scene to choose the meaning.

qti-simple-choice._: selfish

qti-feedback-inline._: Great job—you inferred a character trait by using key details. The drivers seem selfish because the car “threw a huge cloud of dust,” their wagon fell “on its side in the ditch,” and the car just “got smaller and smaller” as it drove away without helping. Next time, look at what characters do and how their actions affect others, and ask, “What does this show about what they care about?”

qti-simple-choice._: farmers

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have chosen “farmers” because it names a type of person, but the story never says the people in the car are farmers. Look at “You mean drivers! You road hogs!” and how the car scared the horse and sped away—this shows the drivers were being selfish, so the correct answer is “selfish.” Next time, make sure your answer is a describing word that fits how the characters act, and use the clues the text gives you.

qti-prompt.p: After lunch, Toad convinced his friends to go on a trip by

qti-simple-choice._: promising them good food along the way.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the part about the food being good at Toad Hall, but the passage says Toad “told Mole all about the fun they would have,” which is how he convinced them. So the correct answer is telling them about the fun they would have, not promising good food. Next time, reread the sentence that explains how a character convinces someone and pick the answer that matches those words.

qti-simple-choice._: asking them to help load the wagon.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on what happened after they decided to go, but the text says, “He told Mole all about the fun they would have… In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon,” showing loading the wagon happened later, not what convinced them. The correct answer is telling them about the fun they would have because that’s how Toad talked them into the trip. Next time, reread to find the cause (what changed their minds) and not just the next action.

qti-simple-choice._: telling them about the fun they would have.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully identified key details by noticing that Toad convinced them by telling about the fun they’d have. The text supports this: “He told Mole all about the fun they would have on the open road… He made it sound like the best thing in the world.” When you answer similar questions, look for cause-and-effect clues—ask, “What did the character say or do that made this happen?”

qti-simple-choice._: showing them his beautiful yellow wagon.

qti-feedback-inline._: You may have focused on the wagon because the text says “some people stopped to say nice things about their beautiful wagon,” but that happens after they already started the trip. In the lunch scene, “He told Mole all about the fun they would have” and Toad “was very good at talking people into things,” so the correct answer is telling them about the fun they would have. Next time, reread the part that matches the question and make sure your answer fits that moment in the story.

items.title: Quiz Question

p: Read the sentence from the passage.
"He did not want to disappoint his friends. So after lunch, they loaded up the wagon and set off on their adventure."
What does this sentence show about Rat?

qti-simple-choice._: Rat cares more about his friends than his own wishes.

qti-feedback-inline._: You successfully inferred a character trait by noticing why Rat changed his mind. The text supports this: “In the end, Rat let Toad and Mole change his mind.
